questions.question: A 10 N force pulls a box 5 m across a floor in the same direction as the force. The work done is:
A gardener pushes a lawnmower with a force of 100 N at an angle of $60^{\circ}$ to the horizontal. How much work is done in pushing the mower 10 m?
A 2 kg book is lifted 2 m upward at a constant speed. How much work is done by the person lifting it? (Use $g = 10 \text{ m/s}^2$)
A 2 kg book is lifted 2 m upward at a constant speed. How much work is done by gravity on the book during the lift?
A 500 N force is applied to a wall, but the wall does not move. The work done is:
options: Depends on the time spent pushing.

questions.question: A crate is pushed 12 m across a floor. The applied force does $600 \text{ J}$ of work, and friction does $-200 \text{ J}$ of work. What is the net work?
A 20 N force acts at an angle of $30^{\circ}$ above the horizontal. If the object moves 10 m horizontally, the work done is approximately:
A 5 kg block slides 4 m down a frictionless $30^{\circ}$ incline. How much work does the Normal Force do on the block?
questions.explanation: Normal force is perpendicular to displacement, so $W = 0$ J.

questions.question: An object is being pulled at a constant velocity. If the work done by the pulling force is $150 \text{ J}$, what must be the work done by friction?
A tug-of-war team pulls the rope with a force of 1000 N, but the other team pulls harder and moves them 2 m in the opposite direction. The work done by the first team on the rope is:
questions.explanation: Force and displacement are opposite: $W = 1000 \times 2 \times \cos180° = -2000$ J.

scoreMessages.70: Good work! Review how angle affects work and the sign of work.
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Focus on $W = Fd\cos\theta$ and identifying when work is zero.
scoreMessages.0: Let's review. Study the basic work formula and practice with different angles.
